Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Geobiological Systems Science: Providing Connectivity across Molecular and Environmental Scales

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) program is focused on the geomicrobiology of complex microbiological systems, and brings together expertise in hydrodynamics, geochemistry, microbial ecology, biochemistry and genomics. The primary goal of this research and education program is to train students to use consistent and coherent interdisciplinary approaches in the study of microbial communities that will lead to a more comprehensive understanding of the important interface between the biosphere and geosphere. The novel training program encompasses research scientists focused on the microbiology of extreme thermal, psychrophilic, or industrial biofilm communities. Graduate students in this program participate in an integrated four-semester course sequence, professional workshops, internships at national and international laboratories, mentoring activities for Native American high-school student summer interns and seminar programs in the Center for Biofilm Engineering (CBE) and Thermal Biology Institute (TBI). Graduates from this IGERT program will be well-prepared to address the complexity of microbial processes in any system, while maintaining significant disciplinary depth. The broader impacts of this graduate training program are extensive, and include partnerships with existing centers of excellence in Thermal Biology, Cold Regions Research, and Biofilm Engineering. Outreach is an integral part of the educational experience and graduate students in this program will participate and assist with one or more important outreach activities including a formal K-12 science-teacher course, scientific workshops, industrial partner programs, training for Yellowstone National Park (YNP) interpretive staff, field trips for K-12 students, educational exhibits at the Museum of the Rockies and the Old Faithful Visitor Museum, mentoring Native American high school and undergraduate students, and development of digital libraries and web content in collaboration with the YNP Research Coordination Network. These broader impacts are synergistic in supporting the diverse educational goals of an IGERT program, and in further developing literacy in the geobiological sciences. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IGERT Program at Montana State University provided exceptional and exciting opportunities for transformative and interdisciplinary graduate training in the microbiological sciences. Geobiological systems are complex and their study requires the convergence of numerous disciplines across the earth, environmental, engineering and molecular sciences. Core faculty with expertise in hydrodynamics, geochemistry, microbial ecology, biochemistry, genetics and engineering were integrated in courses developed and designed to enhance fluency across different scientific foci, and to develop skills for examining, describing and/or engineering microbial communities. IGERT graduate students were recruited from a variety of component disciplines and were trained in a multidisciplinary framework focused on bridging multiple scales of observation in geobiology. IGERT Ph.D. students received additional training through short-courses, laboratory rotations, domestic and international internships, and professional meetings. 

 

Faculty and students from seven departments and three colleges (representing three centers of excellence in science and engineering) were involved in the MSU IGERT Program, and a total of 25 Ph.D. students were supported for a portion of their graduate training. Students recruited to the program benefited from significant research expertise and extramural grant funding by individual principal investigators involved in the program. IGERT graduate students made substantial and exciting contributions to respective disciplines, and several reports have been published in the top science journals (e.g., Nature), and have been reported in the national and/or international news (e.g., new research findings in Antarctica, Yellowstone National Park, algal biofuels). Research conducted by IGERT students at collaborating international laboratories was extremely productive and resulted in synergistic efforts among MSU scientists and other leaders in the international arena. The international component of our program was very successful, and provided students with unparalleled opportunities for scientific, professional and personal growth. Several of our IGERT students won national awards at scientific conferences, and/or received fellowships secured from their own individual proposal writing efforts, which were catalyzed by one of the courses offered within the IGERT curriculum. Finally, significant institutional support and sustainable development towards broad goals in graduate education were achieved during the life of the project (e.g., tuition support, cross-listing of interdisciplinary graduate courses).

 

The MSU IGERT program in Geobiological Sciences benefited from existing centers of excellence in Thermal Biology, Cold Regions Research, and Biofilm Engineering. Our IGERT students participated in a substantive number of outreach activities occurring within these centers of excellence, including formal K-12 science-teacher coursework, extensive undergraduate research scholar mentoring, scientific workshops, technical advisory meetings, industrial partner programs, training for Yellowstone National Park (YNP) interpretive staff, development of brochures and trail guides, field trips for K-12 students, evening public lecture series, and educational exhibits at the Museum of the Rockies and the Old Faithful Visitor Museum. IGERT students participated directly in many of these outreach programs, and collectively, contributed to a significant number of broader impacts both on and off-campus.  The MSU IGERT was committed to enhancing the diversity of our faculty mentors, graduate student body, undergraduate research interns and participants in high-school summer training programs.
